boolean.comment: As opposed to true and false, Objective-C stores boolean values as YES and NO, respectively.

signed_integer_16_bit.comment: Signed short integers range from -32768 to 32767.

unsigned_integer_16_bit.comment: Unsigned short integers range from 0 to 65535.

unsigned_integer_64_bit.comment: Unsigned long integers range from 0 to 18446744073709551615.

signed_integer_as_object.comment: NSNumber can store any integer, float, or double. However, it is not commonly used to store floats or doubles because it has a subclass called NSDecimalNumber, which is more precise.

signed_float_32_bit.comment: Floats in Objective-C are precise up to 7 digits.

signed_float_64_bit.comment: Doubles in Objective-C are precise up to 15 digits.

signed_float_as_object.comment: NSDecimalNumber is often used in situations when precision is key, such as storing a user's bank balance.

character.comment: Using %c to output the character value and %i to output the ASCII value.

string_as_object.comment: NSString is immutable, however, Objective-C has a mutable string object called NSMutableString

string_as_array.comment: NSString is built on the C version of strings, which are arrays of characters. When using an NSString, you can use index notation to access specific characters.
